hints_html:
There are three key values to note - what happens at a and what happens at the two locations where the function goes from positive to negative?

Don’t forget, if you start at a and go left you actually get more negative since integrals also encode a sense of direction.

Your function should be smooth (meaning differentiable everywhere - so no corners allowed!)
hints_latex:
There are three key values to note - what happens at \emph{a} and what
happens at the two locations where the function goes from positive to
negative?

Don't forget, if you start at \emph{a} and go left you actually get more
negative since integrals also encode a sense of direction.

Your function should be smooth (meaning differentiable everywhere - so
no corners allowed!)
hints_raw:
There are three key values to note - what happens at ''a'' and what happens at the two locations where the function goes from positive to negative?
Don't forget, if you start at ''a'' and go left you actually get more negative since integrals also encode a sense of direction.
Your function should be smooth (meaning differentiable everywhere - so no corners allowed!)
sols_html:
Attached is a picture. Notice that there is a local minimum at \(\displaystyle x = -0.4\) and a local maximum at \(\displaystyle x = -1.4\). Also note that plugging in a into the integral gives

\(\displaystyle A(a) = \int_{a}^{a}f(s)\,ds = 0\).
sols_raw:
Attached is a picture. Notice that there is a local minimum at <math> \displaystyle x = -0.4</math> and a local maximum at <math> \displaystyle x = -1.4</math>. Also note that plugging in ''a'' into the integral gives 

<math> \displaystyle A(a) = \int_{a}^{a}f(s)\,ds = 0</math>.

:[[File:M103W2013Q9Answer.jpg|300px]]
statement_html:
Sketching Antiderivatives

Consider the sketch \(\displaystyle f(x)\) below.

Provide a sketch of the antiderivative \(\displaystyle A(x) = \int_{a}^{x}f(s)\,ds\) for \(\displaystyle -1.5 < x < 1.5\). Make sure to clearly indicate local maxima and minima of \(\displaystyle A(x)\)
statement_latex:
\textbf{Sketching Antiderivatives}

Consider the sketch $\displaystyle f(x)$ below.

Provide a sketch of the antiderivative
$\displaystyle A(x) = \int_{a}^{x}f(s)\,ds$ for
$\displaystyle -1.5 < x < 1.5$. Make sure to clearly indicate local
maxima and minima of $\displaystyle A(x)$

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH103/April_2013/M103W2013Q9Question.jpg}
statement_raw:
'''Sketching Antiderivatives'''

Consider the sketch <math> \displaystyle f(x)</math> below.

Provide a sketch of the antiderivative <math> \displaystyle A(x) = \int_{a}^{x}f(s)\,ds</math> for <math> \displaystyle -1.5 < x < 1.5</math>. Make sure to clearly indicate local maxima and minima of <math> \displaystyle A(x)</math>

[[File:M103W2013Q9Question.jpg|300px]]
